text: The Lord gave this message to Joel son of Pethuel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear this, you leaders of the people.
    Listen, all who live in the land.
In all your history,
    has anything like this happened before?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell your children about it in the years to come,
    and let your children tell their children.
    Pass the story down from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After the cutting locusts finished eating the crops,
    the swarming locusts took what was left!
After them came the hopping locusts,
    and then the stripping locusts, too!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wake up, you drunkards, and weep!
    Wail, all you wine-drinkers!
All the grapes are ruined,
    and all your sweet wine is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A vast army of locusts has invaded my land,
    a terrible army too numerous to count.
Its teeth are like lions’ teeth,
    its fangs like those of a lioness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It has destroyed my grapevines
    and ruined my fig trees,
stripping their bark and destroying it,
    leaving the branches white and bare.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Weep like a bride dressed in black,
    mourning the death of her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For there is no grain or wine
    to offer at the Temple of the Lord.
So the priests are in mourning.
    The ministers of the Lord are weeping.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fields are ruined,
    the land is stripped bare.
The grain is destroyed,
    the grapes have shriveled,
    and the olive oil is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Despair, all you farmers!
    Wail, all you vine growers!
Weep, because the wheat and barley—
    all the crops of the field—are ruined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The grapevines have dried up,
    and the fig trees have withered.
The pomegranate trees, palm trees, and apple trees—
    all the fruit trees—have dried up.
    And the people’s joy has dried up with them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dress yourselves in burlap and weep, you priests!
    Wail, you who serve before the altar!
Come, spend the night in burlap,
    you ministers of my God.
For there is no grain or wine
    to offer at the Temple of your God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Announce a time of fasting;
    call the people together for a solemn meeting.
Bring the leaders
    and all the people of the land
into the Temple of the Lord your God,
    and cry out to him there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The day of the Lord is near,
    the day when destruction comes from the Almighty.
    How terrible that day will be!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our food disappears before our very eyes.
    No joyful celebrations are held in the house of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The seeds die in the parched ground,
    and the grain crops fail.
The barns stand empty,
    and granaries are abandoned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How the animals moan with hunger!
    The herds of cattle wander about confused,
because they have no pasture.
    The flocks of sheep and goats bleat in misery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, help us!
The fire has consumed the wilderness pastures,
    and flames have burned up all the trees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even the wild animals cry out to you
    because the streams have dried up,
    and fire has consumed the wilderness pastures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sound the trumpet in Jerusalem!
    Raise the alarm on my holy mountain!
Let everyone tremble in fear
    because the day of the Lord is upon us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is a day of darkness and gloom,
    a day of thick clouds and deep blackness.
Suddenly, like dawn spreading across the mountains,
    a great and mighty army appears.
Nothing like it has been seen before
    or will ever be seen again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire burns in front of them,
    and flames follow after them.
Ahead of them the land lies
    as beautiful as the Garden of Eden.
Behind them is nothing but desolation;
    not one thing escapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They look like horses;
    they charge forward like warhorses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at them as they leap along the mountaintops.
    Listen to the noise they make—like the rumbling of chariots,
like the roar of fire sweeping across a field of stubble,
    or like a mighty army moving into battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear grips all the people;
    every face grows pale with terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The attackers march like warriors
    and scale city walls like soldiers.
Straight forward they march,
    never breaking rank.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They never jostle each other;
    each moves in exactly the right position.
They break through defenses
    without missing a step.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They swarm over the city
    and run along its walls.
They enter all the houses,
    climbing like thieves through the windows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth quakes as they advance,
    and the heavens tremble.
The sun and moon grow dark,
    and the stars no longer shine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is at the head of the column.
    He leads them with a shout.
This is his mighty army,
    and they follow his orders.
The day of the Lord is an awesome, terrible thing.
    Who can possibly survive?
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why the Lord says,
    “Turn to me now, while there is time.
Give me your hearts.
    Come with fasting, weeping, and mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t tear your clothing in your grief,
    but tear your hearts instead.”
Return to the Lord your God,
    for he is merciful and compassionate,
slow to get angry and filled with unfailing love.
    He is eager to relent and not punish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who knows? Perhaps he will give you a reprieve,
    sending you a blessing instead of this curse.
Perhaps you will be able to offer grain and wine
    to the Lord your God as before.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blow the ram’s horn in Jerusalem!
    Announce a time of fasting;
call the people together
    for a solemn meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gather all the people—
    the elders, the children, and even the babies.
Call the bridegroom from his quarters
    and the bride from her private room.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the priests, who minister in the Lord’s presence,
    stand and weep between the entry room to the Temple and the altar.
Let them pray, “Spare your people, Lord!
    Don’t let your special possession become an object of mockery.
Don’t let them become a joke for unbelieving foreigners who say,
    ‘Has the God of Israel left them?’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord will pity his people
    and jealously guard the honor of his land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will reply,
“Look! I am sending you grain and new wine and olive oil,
    enough to satisfy your needs.
You will no longer be an object of mockery
    among the surrounding nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will drive away these armies from the north.
    I will send them into the parched wastelands.
Those in the front will be driven into the Dead Sea,
    and those at the rear into the Mediterranean.
The stench of their rotting bodies will rise over the land.”
Surely the Lord has done great things!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be afraid, O land.
Be glad now and rejoice,
    for the Lord has done great things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be afraid, you animals of the field,
    for the wilderness pastures will soon be green.
The trees will again be filled with fruit;
    fig trees and grapevines will be loaded down once more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rejoice, you people of Jerusalem!
    Rejoice in the Lord your God!
For the rain he sends demonstrates his faithfulness.
    Once more the autumn rains will come,
    as well as the rains of spring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The threshing floors will again be piled high with grain,
    and the presses will overflow with new wine and olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord says, “I will give you back what you lost
    to the swarming locusts, the hopping locusts,
the stripping locusts, and the cutting locusts.
    It was I who sent this great destroying army against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once again you will have all the food you want,
    and you will praise the Lord your God,
who does these miracles for you.
    Never again will my people be disgraced.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will know that I am among my people Israel,
    that I am the Lord your God, and there is no other.
    Never again will my people be disgraced.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then, after doing all those things,
    I will pour out my Spirit upon all people.
Your sons and daughters will prophesy.
    Your old men will dream dreams,
    and your young men will see visions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In those days I will pour out my Spirit
    even on servants—men and women alike.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will cause wonders in the heavens and on the earth—
    blood and fire and columns of smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sun will become dark,
    and the moon will turn blood red
    before that great and terrible day of the Lord arrives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But everyone who calls on the name of the Lord
    will be saved,
for some on Mount Zion in Jerusalem will escape,
    just as the Lord has said.
These will be among the survivors
    whom the Lord has called.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“At the time of those events,” says the Lord,
    “when I restore the prosperity of Judah and Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They threw dice to decide which of my people
    would be their slaves.
They traded boys to obtain prostitutes
    and sold girls for enough wine to get drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What do you have against me, Tyre and Sidon and you cities of Philistia? Are you trying to take revenge on me? If you are, then watch out! I will strike swiftly and pay you back for everything you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have taken my silver and gold and all my precious treasures, and have carried them off to your pagan temples.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have sold the people of Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks, so they could take them far from their homeland.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But I will bring them back from all the places to which you sold them, and I will pay you back for everything you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will sell your sons and daughters to the people of Judah, and they will sell them to the people of Arabia, a nation far away. I, the Lord, have spoken!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to the nations far and wide:
    “Get ready for war!
Call out your best warriors.
    Let all your fighting men advance for the attack.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hammer your plowshares into swords
    and your pruning hooks into spears.
    Train even your weaklings to be warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come quickly, all you nations everywhere.
    Gather together in the valley.”
And now, O Lord, call out your warriors!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let the nations be called to arms.
    Let them march to the valley of Jehoshaphat.
There I, the Lord, will sit
    to pronounce judgment on them all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Swing the sickle,
    for the harvest is ripe.
Come, tread the grapes,
    for the winepress is full.
The storage vats are overflowing
    with the wickedness of these people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thousands upon thousands are waiting in the valley of decision.
    There the day of the Lord will soon arrive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sun and moon will grow dark,
    and the stars will no longer shine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord’s voice will roar from Zion
    and thunder from Jerusalem,
    and the heavens and the earth will shake.
But the Lord will be a refuge for his people,
    a strong fortress for the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then you will know that I, the Lord your God,
    live in Zion, my holy mountain.
Jerusalem will be holy forever,
    and foreign armies will never conquer her again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day the mountains will drip with sweet wine,
    and the hills will flow with milk.
Water will fill the streambeds of Judah,
    and a fountain will burst forth from the Lord’s Temple,
    watering the arid valley of acacias.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Egypt will become a wasteland
    and Edom will become a wilderness,
because they attacked the people of Judah
    and killed innocent people in their land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But Judah will be filled with people forever,
    and Jerusalem will endure through all generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will pardon my people’s crimes,
    which I have not yet pardoned;
and I, the Lord, will make my home
    in Jerusalem with my people.”
speaker: Narrator
